sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Type 2 diabetes mellitus, Adjunct to diet and exercise: initial dose, 0.75 mg SUBQ once weekly; may be increased to MAX of 1.5 mg SUBQ once weekly

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy have not been established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment (including ESRD): no dose adjustment recommended; use caution when initiating therapy or titrating upward
  • hepatic impairment: use with caution
  • concomitant use with insulin or insulin secretagogues: consider reducing insulin or insulin secretagogue dose

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Type 2 diabetes mellitus, Adjunct to diet and exercise

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Subcutaneous (Solution)
Dulaglutide caused thyroid C-cell tumors in rats, that was related to dose and duration of treatment. However, it is unknown if dulaglutide causes thyroid C-cell tumors, including medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), in humans. Dulaglutide is contraindicated in patients who have a personal or family history of MTC and in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type 2. The value of monitoring calcitonin levels or thyroid ultrasound routinely is uncertain.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to dulaglutide or any of its components
  • multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type 2 or personal or family history of medullary thyroid carcinoma

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- thyroid C-cell tumors have been reported in rats; it is unknown if thyroid C-cell tumors may occur in humans
  • Gastrointestinal:
  • -- pancreatitis has been reported; monitor for signs and symptoms, and permanently discontinue if confirmed
  • -- severe gastrointestinal adverse reactions may occur; not recommended in patients with severe gastrointestinal disease, including severe gastroparesis
  • Renal:
  • -- acute renal failure and worsening of chronic renal failure have been reported, especially with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or dehydration; in patients with renal impairment, use caution when starting or adjusting dosage and monitor renal function with severe adverse gastrointestinal reactions

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (6.5% to 9.4%), Decrease in appetite (4.9% to 8.6%), Diarrhea (8.9% to 12.6%), Nausea (12.4% to 21.1%), Vomiting (6% to 12.7%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Atrioventricular block, First degree (1.7% to 2.3%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypoglycemia (2.6% to 85%), Malignant tumor of thyroid gland
  • Gastrointestinal:Pancreatitis
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (0.5%)
  • Renal:Acute renal failure, Chronic renal failure, Exacerbation

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Dulaglutide is a glucagon-like peptide (GLP-1) receptor agonist. Insulin release is stimulated in a glucose-dependent manner via activation of GLP-1 receptors on pancreatic beta cells. Glucagon secretion is also reduced and gastric emptying is delayed.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
General Information
  • do not mix with other antidiabetic agents in same syringe
  • administer separately from insulin; may be administered in the same body region but not in adjacent sites
  • inject subQ into the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm and rotate sites each week
  • do not administer IM or IV
  • administer missed dose if at least 72 hours until next scheduled dose, and administer next scheduled dose on regularly scheduled day; if next scheduled dose less than 72 hours away, skip missed dose and administer on next scheduled dose day

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improved type 2 diabetes glycemic control is indicative of efficacy.
  • renal function, in patients with renal impairment who report severe gastrointestinal reactions
  • blood glucose and HbA1c levels, periodically during diabetic therapy
  • signs and symptoms of pancreatitis, after treatment initiation

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Counsel patient to report symptoms of pancreatitis or renal failure.
  • Advise patient to report hypoglycemia if used with insulin or a sulfonylurea.
  • Side effects may include decreased appetite, nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhea, or vomiting.
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of a thyroid tumor.
  • Teach patient proper technique and placement of injections.
  • Tell patient to maintain adequate hydration.
  • Instruct patient to take a missed dose as soon as possible if there are at least 3 days (72 hours) before the next scheduled dose, but if less than 3 days remain skip the missed dose.
